title: 109_s2630
content: The "Truth in Caller ID Act of 2006" prohibits the manipulation of caller identification information. Section 227 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a new subsection (e) that prohibits the transmission of misleading or inaccurate caller identification information in the United States. This is in line with the "Truth in Caller ID Act of 2006" which already prohibits the manipulation of caller identification information. The new subsection (e) of Section 227 of the Communications Act of 1934 prohibits blocking caller identification information transmission. The FCC must create regulations within 6 months, including exemptions for law enforcement agencies or court orders. The regulations must exempt transmissions for authorized law enforcement activities or court-ordered caller identification manipulation. The FCC must report to Congress within 6 months on the need for additional legislation regarding inaccurate caller identification information in successor technologies. The FCC can impose civil forfeiture penalties up to $10,000 for each violation of regulations regarding telecommunications or IP-enabled voice services. The penalty can be tripled for continuing violations. The FCC can impose civil forfeiture penalties up to $10,000 for each violation of regulations regarding telecommunications or IP-enabled voice services, with a maximum of $1,000,000 for any single act or failure to act. The penalty can be tripled for continuing violations, and recovery is possible under section 504(a) with a 2-year statute of limitations. No forfeiture liability can be determined without proper notice as required by section 503(b)(3) or section 503(b)(4). The FCC can impose civil forfeiture penalties of up to $10,000 for each violation of regulations on telecommunications or IP-enabled voice services. For violations occurring more than 2 years prior to notice issuance, no penalty can be imposed. Criminal fines of up to $10,000 per violation, or 3 times that amount for each day of a continuing violation, can be imposed for willful and knowing violations. States can also enforce these regulations. States can enforce FCC regulations through civil actions in federal court to protect residents from violations, with penalties including fines and imprisonment. The chief legal officer or State officer must provide written notice to the Commission before initiating a civil action, including a copy of the complaint. The Commission may intervene in the civil action upon receiving the notice and be heard on all matters arising in the case. The chief legal officer or State officer can bring civil actions in federal court to enforce FCC regulations. They must notify the Commission before filing a complaint, and the Commission can intervene in the case. The civil action must be filed in a district court of the United States. In civil actions brought to enforce FCC regulations, process serving and joining parties in the action are not limited by district or state boundaries under section 1391 of title 28, United States Code. The FCC regulations allow for process serving and joining parties in civil actions without limitations based on district or state boundaries. Additionally, during federal enforcement actions, states are restricted from taking action under the same section. Definitions include caller identification information provided by a caller identification service. The curr_chunk discusses caller identification services and IP-enabled voice services, defining them as services or devices that provide information about the origination of a call made using telecommunications or IP-enabled voice services. The curr_chunk defines 'enabled voice service' as real-time 2-way voice communications transmitted through customer premises equipment using TCP/IP protocol for a fee with interconnection capability to the public switched telephone network.
